Detection of samples To determine whether the SPF chickens were successfully infected, we measured gene expression levels of ALV-J-specific genes from chickens infected with the SCAU-HN06 virus strain. the presence of hemangiomas is a characteristic of ALV-J infection. the tumors were typical cavernous hemangiomas with malignant vessel hyperplasia visible as a closely packed meshwork of blood vessels. PCR tests on the genomic DNA of the three sick chicken spleens were all positive. we detected no related viral infections as judged by the absence of amplicons using primers specific to ALV-A, ALV-B, MDV, and REV. the PCR tests of three normal chickens from the same flock were negative. we examined whether ALV-J induces or inhibits innate immune host responses during both early and late phases of infection. transcriptome analysis of splenic genes related to innate immunity based on previous study of ALV-J-induced tumors in white (Recessive) Plymouth Rock chickens. chicken MDA5 was the main ALV-J-sensing pattern-recognition receptor during the late infection phase in vivo. IL-6, IL-10, IL-1, and IFN- showed no significant differences between the groups of SPF chicks from 1 to 7 d.p.i. western blot analysis of the IRF1 and STAT1 expression in the late phases of ALV-J infection. cytokine levels were not significantly different between the infected chick group and the control group from 1 to 7 d.p.i. the nature of the exact innate sensors that detect ALV-J had remained elusive until now. recognition of HIV-1 by TLR7 does not require retroviral replication, and only requires attachment and endocytosis. IL-6, IL-1, and IFN- can induce expression of IFN-stimulated genes by activating the JAK-STAT pathway. this would lead to regulation of ISG12-1 expression via JAK-STAT pathway activation at 1 d.p.i. however, the early antiviral innate immune response was too weak to resist ALV-J invasion. the antiviral activity of IRF1 was inhibited during the late phase of ALV-J infection. we hypothesize that STAT1 levels are decreased in chickens with tumors induced by ALV-J infection.
